Abstract:
Characterizing the processes leading to deforestation is crucial for developing and implementing targeted forest conservation and management policies. This work develops a deep learning model called ForestNet to classify the drivers of primary forest loss in Indonesia, a country with one of the highest deforestation rates in the world. Using satellite imagery, ForestNet identifies the direct drivers of deforestation in forest loss patches of any size. A dataset of Landsat 8 satellite images of known forest loss events paired with driver annotations from expert interpreters is curated and used to train and validate the models, demonstrating that ForestNet substantially outperforms other standard driver classification approaches. The dataset is publicly available at https://stanfordmlgroup.github.io/projects/forestnet.

Introduction:
The preservation of forests is critical for preventing loss of biodiversity, managing air and water quality, and mitigating climate change. Forest loss in the tropics contributes to around 10% of annual global greenhouse gas emissions and must be reduced to decrease the potential for climate tipping points. The direct drivers of tropical deforestation include natural events like wildfires, as well as human-induced land uses such as industrial and smallholder agricultural development. Determining the extent to which these processes contribute to forest loss enables companies to fulfill their zero-deforestation commitments and helps decision-makers design, implement, and enforce targeted conservation and management policies. Indonesia has one of the highest rates of primary forest loss in the tropics, making it among the largest emitters of greenhouse gases worldwide.

Recent work using high-resolution satellite imagery to manually classify the direct drivers of forest loss in Indonesia provides critical information about the nationwide causes of deforestation. Automating driver classification would enable more spatially-broad and temporally-dense driver attribution with significant implications for forest conservation policies. The growth in availability of high-resolution satellite imagery, coupled with advancements in deep learning methods, presents opportunities to automatically derive geospatial insights at scale.

Convolutional neural networks (CNNs) have enabled various satellite-image-based applications, including extracting socioeconomic data for tracking poverty, classifying land use for urban planning, and identifying the locations of solar photovoltaics in the U.S. to support the adoption of solar electricity. Prior work has developed decision-tree-based models and other machine learning techniques to automatically identify land-use conversion following deforestation, but these methods do not leverage the complete contextual information provided by satellite imagery and heavily depend on data that is not widely available at high resolution.

In this work, we train CNNs to identify the direct drivers (plantation, smallholder agriculture, grassland/shrubland, or other drivers) of primary forest loss using satellite imagery in Indonesia. This task is challenging due to the heterogeneity of drivers within images and driver classes, the rapid evolution of landscapes over time, and the lack of expert-annotated data. We highlight three key technical developments that enable high classification performance on this task, including pre-training on a large land cover dataset, data augmentation using satellite revisits, and multi-modal fusion with auxiliary predictors to complement the satellite imagery. Our best model, called ForestNet, substantially outperforms standard driver classification approaches.

All data used in this study is publicly available to support future research on forest loss driver classification.

Methods:
2.1 Forest Loss Events and Driver Annotations
The coordinates of forest loss events and driver annotations used in this work were curated in [11]. Global Forest Change (GFC) published maps were used to obtain a random sample of primary natural forest loss events at 30m resolution from 2001 to 2016. Each forest loss region is represented as a polygon and is associated with a year indicating the time of the event.

Table 1: Number of events per driver class in the training, validation, and test sets.

| Driver Class | Training | Validation | Test |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Plantation | 686 | 219 | 265 |
| Smallholder Agriculture | 556 | 138 | 207 |
| Grassland/Shrubland | 143 | 47 | 85 |
| Other | 231 | 70 | 112 |
| Total | 1,616 | 474 | 669 |

Note: Each class was created by combining driver categories from [11] as shown in Table A1 in the Appendix.
